study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of bariatric surgery as part of a progressive therapeutic approach for obesity-related nephropathy (ORN), alongside lifestyle enhancements and pharmacotherapy.
results_summary: The study highlights bariatric surgery as a potential treatment for ORN, emphasizing its inclusion in a multi-modal approach to weight reduction, mitigating proteinuria, and preserving renal function, though specific outcomes of the surgery are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity-related nephropathy (ORN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of metabolic and bariatric surgeries (MBS) on brain function and anatomy using MRI technology.
results_summary: The study found that MBS reversed neuroanatomic alterations and improved functional connectivity, cognitive performance, memory, executive function, and attention, while reducing gustatory brain responses to food cues. Improved neural functioning and metabolic health were also observed following weight loss induced by bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity (approximately 500 million worldwide).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the rates and outcomes of bariatric and metabolic surgery (BMS) between patients in metropolitan versus provincial areas in the Northern region of Aotearoa New Zealand.
results_summary: The study found that BMS rates were 6.1 times higher in metropolitan areas, with metropolitan patients being less obese and having lower diabetes rates. Provincial patients showed higher diabetes resolution, but Māori were underrepresented in both cohorts.
population_specificity: Patients with class III obesity domiciled in metropolitan or provincial areas in the Northern region of Aotearoa New Zealand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the associations between different bariatric surgery procedures (SG, RYGB, adjustable gastric banding) and their effects on OSA remission, employment prospects, and body image.
results_summary: The study found significantly lower OSA remission in SG compared to RYGB in observational studies but no difference in RCTs. SG showed higher OSA remission than adjustable gastric banding. No significant differences were observed in employment status or body image improvements between surgery types.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed).
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from short-term (1-2 years) to longer-term (3+ years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different doses of vitamin D supplementation (low, moderate, high) or placebo in adults undergoing bariatric surgery to determine their impact on skeletal health and other outcomes.
results_summary: Moderate-dose vitamin D may improve vitamin D status with little to no effect on parathyroid hormone levels compared to placebo, while high-dose vitamin D may further increase vitamin D levels but with uncertain effects on adverse events. The evidence is limited and uncertain for most outcomes, including fractures and adverse events.
population_specificity: Adults living with obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Moderate dose (600 IU/day to 3500 IU/day), high dose (greater than 3500 IU/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of dexmedetomidine (DX) in reducing the incidence and severity of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) in laparoscopic bariatric surgeries.
results_summary: DX significantly reduced the incidence of PONV and Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) scores, likely due to its sympatholytic effect, reduced postoperative pain, and lower opioid usage. It was more effective when surgery duration was <120 minutes and when delivered as a continuous infusion without a loading dose.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (delivery methods compared: continuous infusion without loading dose vs. infusion after loading dose).
study_duration: Duration of surgery (<120 minutes noted for better efficacy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the rates and predictors of remission and relapse of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in individuals undergoing sleeve gastrectomy (SG) or one-anastomosis gastric bypass (OAGB).
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery led to a T2DM remission rate of 61.4 per 1000 person-months and a relapse rate of 5.7 per 1000 person-months, with no significant differences between SG and OAGB. Predictors of remission included history of insulin therapy and T2DM duration, while treatment with ≥2 glucose-lowering agents predicted relapse.
population_specificity: 891 patients (82.5% female) with concomitant T2DM and obesity (BMI ≥ 30.0 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of GLP-1RA-based treatments on fat-free mass (FFM) loss compared to other weight loss interventions, including bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that GLP-1RA-based treatments resulted in 20-40% fat-free mass loss, with most trials reporting FFM loss exceeding 25%. The heterogeneity in data was attributed to indirect measurement methods like DXA, which does not directly assess skeletal muscle mass.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes or obesity undergoing weight loss interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of metabolic and bariatric surgery, particularly vertical sleeve gastrectomy, as a treatment for severe obesity in adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that metabolic and bariatric surgery is an effective treatment for severe obesity in adolescents, endorsed by major pediatric organizations. Post-operative care should include monitoring for complications, weight regain, micronutrient deficiencies, and psychological challenges.
population_specificity: Adolescents with severe obesity, particularly racial/ethnic minority subgroups and rural communities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the quality of recovery after laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy between patients receiving erector spinae plane block versus serratus anterior plane block plus subcostal TAP block.
results_summary: The abstract describes a proposed study protocol but does not report results, as it is a trial design rather than a completed study.
population_specificity: Seventy patients presenting for laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy at a tertiary hospital in Ireland.
effective_dosage: Same dose of the same local anesthetic for both groups (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms of action of DPP-IV and its inhibitors in obesity and metabolic homeostasis, as well as their role in treating obesity-related chronic diseases.
results_summary: The study found that DPP-IV and its inhibitors play a significant role in metabolic regulation, reducing obesity-related inflammation, improving hepatic steatosis, lowering cardiovascular risk, and potentially decreasing COVID-19 risk.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese patients with metabolic and inflammatory conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current literature on learning curves for surgeons newly adopting robotic bariatric surgery and its implications for safety, efficiency, and outcomes.
results_summary: The review found that robotic bariatric surgery shows significant reductions in operative time, with learning curves as short as 11 cases, and some studies reported improved outcomes post-learning curve. However, clinical outcome reporting was limited, and long-term outcomes were consistent with existing literature but lacked comparison between learning curve groups.
population_specificity: Surgeons newly adopting robotic bariatric surgery and their patients (1,237 patients across 11 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) on type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) remission, comparing their efficacy, safety, and durability to GLP-1 agonists.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to be highly effective in treating and inducing remission of T2DM, with post-surgical patients showing enhanced glycemic control. Both surgical interventions and GLP-1 agonists were effective in achieving T2DM remission, though long-term follow-up and randomized controlled trials are needed for further comparison.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether withdrawing PEEP before emergence preoxygenation would better maintain postoperative oxygenation in obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in postoperative oxygenation between patients who maintained PEEP during awakening and those with zero PEEP. Both groups experienced impaired oxygenation postoperatively, though intraoperative oxygenation was excellent.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI 35-50 kg/m²) undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Fixed PEEP of 12 or 14 cmH2O depending on BMI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether erector spinae plane block (ESPB) combined with multimodal analgesia reduces morphine consumption and improves recovery in patients undergoing laparoscopic metabolic bariatric surgery (MBS).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in morphine consumption, patient satisfaction, postoperative pain scores, or quality of recovery between patients who received ESPB and those who did not. ESPB did not enhance postoperative outcomes following laparoscopic MBS.
population_specificity: 63 patients with severe obesity undergoing laparoscopic MBS (sleeve gastrectomy or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize themes from qualitative research to recommend improvements in post-bariatric surgery clinical care in primary care settings.
results_summary: The study identified seven key themes, including stigma, clinician barriers, patient support needs, and communication issues. Patients sought comprehensive care from PCPs, but barriers like poor communication, limited follow-up, and adverse surgical outcomes hindered optimal care.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery and their primary care practitioners (PCPs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of preoperative micronutrient repletion strategies on micronutrient biochemistry, quality of life, and complication rates in candidates for metabolic and bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Preoperative micronutrient repletion strategies showed varied efficacy, with chronic dosing of oral supplements improving vitamin D levels and multivitamins improving vitamin B6, vitamin C, and folate status, while iron infusion increased ferritin levels but oral iron supplementation had inconsistent effects.
population_specificity: Candidates for metabolic and bariatric surgery, excluding pregnant, lactating individuals, or those undergoing specific bypass procedures.
effective_dosage: Chronic dosing of oral supplements, megadoses of oral supplements, intramuscular injection, intravenous infusion, and mixed methods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify metabolic signatures associated with the resolution of type 2 diabetes after medical therapy or bariatric surgery (RYGB and SG).
results_summary: Bariatric surgery (RYGB and SG) significantly remodeled the circulating metabolome, enhancing lipid and amino acid signaling while reducing xenobiotic metabolites. RYGB specifically correlated with changes in 2-hydroxydecanoate, which was linked to improved fasting glucose levels.
population_specificity: 90 patients (age 49.9 ± 7.6 years; 57.7% female) with type 2 diabetes, randomly assigned to medical therapy, RYGB, or SG.

study_goal: To compare the impact of OAGB vs RYGB on gut microbiota profile and its effects on metabolic and nutritional status.
results_summary: Both OAGB and RYGB led to significant changes in gut microbiota composition, including shifts in bacterial phyla and reduced microbial diversity, but no significant differences were found between the two procedures. The gut microbiota changes may influence medium- or long-term outcomes, suggesting its potential as a biomarker for bariatric surgery results.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of bariatric surgery versus dieting on adipose tissue and skeletal muscle mitochondrial metabolism in obesity.
results_summary: The study found that both bariatric surgery and dieting improve weight loss and metabolism, but their long-term effects on mitochondrial metabolism in adipose tissue and skeletal muscle remain unclear. The review highlights potential molecular pathways for future therapeutic targets.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare weight loss and glucometabolic outcomes between semaglutide and metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) in patients with type 2 diabetes and obesity.
results_summary: MBS resulted in significantly greater weight loss (26.4% vs. 5.2%) and better glycaemic control (63.0% remission vs. 13.9%) compared to semaglutide at 2 years. Both interventions improved weight and glucometabolic outcomes, but MBS was superior.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes and obesity in Sweden.
effective_dosage: Not specified for MBS; semaglutide duration ≥2 years (dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the 3-year outcomes of sleeve gastrectomy in non-diabetic individuals with class I and class II obesity, focusing on weight loss, metabolic features, and surgical complications.
results_summary: The study found that sleeve gastrectomy was similarly effective in both class I and class II obesity groups for weight loss, alleviating cardiovascular risk factors, and improving obesity-related comorbidities, with no significant differences in surgical complications or undesirable outcomes.
population_specificity: Non-diabetic individuals with class I and class II obesity (mean age 36.4 ± 8.5, 93.6% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and long-term outcomes of bariatric surgery (BS) for obesity, including weight loss, metabolic improvements, and potential adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery provides substantial and durable weight loss compared to conservative treatments, but long-term follow-up revealed weight regain in half of patients, nutritional deficiencies in up to 90%, and worsened psychological aspects in some cases. Despite metabolic benefits, the overall impact on patients' proinflammatory and metabolic profiles remains debated.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity who underwent bariatric surgery after failing conservative treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define obesity, discuss diagnostic tools, and evaluate the indications and benefits of bariatric surgery for metabolic and quality-of-life improvements.
results_summary: The study highlights the clinical importance of body composition in obesity diagnosis and underscores the benefits of bariatric surgery for metabolic derangements and quality of life, including potential mechanisms of action.
population_specificity: Patients with excessive fat accumulation, metabolic alterations, and obesity-associated comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in reducing weight and improving comorbid diseases when lifestyle modifications and pharmacotherapy fail.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery is recommended for weight reduction and improvement of comorbid conditions in obese patients when other treatments are ineffective, though continuous monitoring of accompanying diseases is necessary.
population_specificity: Obese patients, including those with metabolically unhealthy obesity (MUO) and metabolically healthy obesity (MHO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between treating pediatric obesity and metabolism-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD), focusing on the safety and efficacy of obesity treatment.
results_summary: The study found that obesity treatment is safe and effective, with a direct link between treating MASLD and pediatric obesity, suggesting positive outcomes for youth with obesity-related conditions.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with obesity in the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review advances in precision medicine for bariatric surgery and discuss future avenues and challenges in personalizing treatment strategies.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that precision medicine, incorporating deep phenotyping and 'omics assays, can enhance the effectiveness and tolerability of bariatric surgery by tailoring treatments to individual patient subsets. Future directions and challenges in the field are also discussed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on precision medicine in bariatrics)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the initial and long-term costs of GLP-1 Receptor Agonists (GLP-1s) to bariatric surgery (sleeve gastrectomy and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass) for obesity treatment.
results_summary: The study found that the ongoing costs of GLP-1s like Saxenda and Wegovy surpass the cost of bariatric surgery within a year, with even the most affordable GLP-1 (Byetta) becoming costlier than surgery after around 1.5 years. The study highlights the financial trade-offs between GLP-1s and bariatric surgery but does not directly assess long-term efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity treatment context in the US).
study_duration: Not specified (cost comparison over time, but no intervention duration detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, safety, efficacy, and durability of endoscopic interventions for addressing weight regain after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that endoscopic interventions are feasible, safe, effective, and durable minimally invasive treatment options for weight regain following bariatric surgery. These procedures offer an alternative to anti-obesity medications and surgical revisions, which have their own challenges and limitations.
population_specificity: Patients experiencing weight regain after bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and endoscopic management of complications (fistulas, leaks, ulcers) following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery is generally safe and effective for obesity and related comorbidities, but adverse events like fistulas, leaks, and ulcers are not uncommon. Endoscopic management is the first-line therapy for these complications, with growing techniques and devices available.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and obesity-related comorbidities undergoing bariatric surgery (Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current literature on iron deficiency in patients with severe obesity and those undergoing metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS), focusing on its clinical significance, diagnostic criteria, and treatment gaps.
results_summary: The study found that iron deficiency remains the most common and clinically significant nutritional complication of MBS, potentially negating the health benefits of surgical weight loss. It highlighted gaps in knowledge regarding iron homeostasis, diagnostic criteria, and treatment efficacy in this population.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity and those undergoing metabolic and bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evolution, popularity, and effectiveness of bariatric surgery as a sustainable treatment for obesity and related diseases.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is recognized as the most sustainable and effective treatment for obesity and related diseases, with sleeve gastrectomy being the most popular procedure over the last decade. The full mechanism of these procedures remains unclear, and there has been growth in revisional and novel surgical techniques.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and related diseases (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the durability of weight loss from bariatric surgery versus pharmacotherapy and lifestyle interventions, and explore the potential of multimodal pharmacotherapy to address post-surgical weight regain.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery induces more durable weight loss than pharmacotherapy or lifestyle interventions alone, but patients often experience weight regain and plateaus; combining pharmacotherapy with surgery may help mitigate these challenges.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity population implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the influence of obesity degree on H. pylori eradication rates in patients undergoing bariatric and metabolic surgery.
results_summary: The study found that H. pylori eradication rates were significantly lower in patients with obesity compared to normal-weight individuals, with the lowest rates observed in severe obesity classes (BMI ≥ 40). Obesity degree correlated with decreased eradication efficacy.
population_specificity: 204 adults (129 with obesity, 75 normal weight) who were H. pylori positive and undergoing bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: 14-day quadruple concomitant treatment (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and outcomes of SADI-S/SADS as an alternative to BPD-DS in bariatric surgery, focusing on weight loss and comorbidity control.
results_summary: SADI-S/SADS showed efficacy in weight loss and medium-to-long-term control of T2DM, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, but nutritional deficiencies (e.g., fat-soluble vitamins, anemia) were frequent. High-quality evidence remains limited, necessitating further RCTs and long-term studies.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: To identify topical areas in macronutrients and Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery (MBS) with sufficient evidence to guide nutrition recommendations.
results_summary: The study identified protein supplementation and "food-focused" interventions as promising areas for MBS nutrition care with potentially sufficient evidence for guidelines, while also highlighting gaps in research. Clinical practice remains guided by consensus and indirect evidence.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery (MBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of a theory-based behavioral intervention on physical activity levels in post-metabolic bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed greater increases in physical activity levels and improved physical function compared to the control group, though no differences were observed in self-efficacy, anthropometrics, cardiovascular, or biochemical parameters.
population_specificity: Forty-four patients undergoing metabolic bariatric surgery at a university hospital in Israel.
effective_dosage: Not specified (behavioral intervention involved a 6-month PA counseling program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of anti-obesity medications (AOM) in bridging the gap between lifestyle treatment and bariatric surgery for pediatric obesity management.
results_summary: The study highlights that AOMs like semaglutide and phentermine/topiramate show substantial effectiveness in BMI reduction with mostly mild to moderate adverse events, but long-term safety and effects beyond BMI remain understudied. Bariatric surgery is noted for its large effects in adolescents with obesity.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 12 years and older with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess and compare the effectiveness of four main conversional metabolic and bariatric surgery (CMBS) sequences on lipid-lowering treatment (LLT) reimbursement and costs after sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and adjustable gastric banding (AGB).
results_summary: The study found that CMBS significantly reduced the need and associated costs of LLT over a 4-year period, with varying discontinuation rates and cost reductions across the four surgical sequences. The most notable cost reductions occurred in the SG-RYGB and AGB-RYGB sequences.
population_specificity: Patients in France who underwent primary SG or AGB between 2012 and 2014, followed until 2020.
study_duration: Follow-up until December 31, 2020 (up to 8 years post-surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between obesity and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), evaluating the role of bariatric surgery and emerging pharmacotherapies in OSA treatment.
results_summary: The study highlights that while bariatric surgery has been a focus for OSA treatment in obese patients, non-anatomical factors also contribute to OSA, necessitating broader treatment strategies. Pharmacological alternatives like incretin agonists show promise but face challenges such as side effects and cost.
population_specificity: Diverse adult populations, including those with and without obesity.

study_goal: To determine the safety and efficacy of a new intra-abdominal anesthetic technique (visceral block) during laparoscopic bariatric operations.
results_summary: The procedure was found to be safe with no adverse events or side effects. A non-statistically significant trend toward reduced opioid use was observed in the first postoperative hours.
population_specificity: 31 patients undergoing bariatric surgery (16 treated with ropivacaine, 15 with saline as control).
effective_dosage: Injection of ropivacaine to the anterior esophagogastric junction fat (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility and limitations of psychological evaluations before bariatric surgery and provide recommendations to improve their predictive validity and clinical value.
results_summary: The study found mixed evidence on the predictive utility of preoperative psychological evaluations for bariatric surgery outcomes, highlighting limitations in existing literature but advocating for continued use as a standard of care when conducted thoroughly.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing metabolic and bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential link between metabolic bariatric surgery (MBS) and eating disorders, the impact of disordered eating behaviors on weight outcomes, and the efficacy of adjunctive treatments.
results_summary: The study found that while eating disorders are rare post-MBS, disordered eating behaviors are more common and linked to suboptimal weight loss. DSM-5 criteria may not adequately assess eating disorders in MBS patients, and preoperative interventions show limited effects, while postoperative intervention evidence remains scarce. GLP-1 RAs show promise for weight loss and binge-eating treatment but require careful risk management.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing metabolic bariatric surgery (MBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the molecular mechanisms by which bariatric surgery improves diabetic cardiomyopathy (DCM) and explore potential therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery, specifically sleeve gastrectomy and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, shows promise in improving diabetes mellitus and DCM, though further research is needed to evaluate the benefits and limitations of these interventions.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity and associated metabolic disorders, including diabetes mellitus and DCM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the tolerability, satisfaction, and protein intake effects of five protein-enhancing strategies (PES) in patients post-bariatric surgery.
results_summary: PES were generally well-tolerated (61% no dietary complaints) and increased protein intake significantly (+10.1 g/day vs. controls). Hydrolysed collagen scored highest on tolerability and satisfaction, while whey showed the highest protein intake increase.
population_specificity: 94 participants scheduled for bariatric surgery (87 analyzed post-dropout).
effective_dosage: 30 g of powder, 2 gels, or protein products added to diet daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and update consensus statements on optimizing antithrombotic drug management for underweight and obese patients, including those undergoing bariatric surgery, due to altered pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics.
results_summary: The study highlights the challenges of managing antithrombotic therapy in underweight and obese individuals, including those post-bariatric surgery, due to metabolic and anatomical changes. It suggests artificial intelligence simulations can help identify optimal drug regimens but notes gaps in knowledge requiring personalized approaches.
population_specificity: Underweight and obese individuals (moderate-to-morbid obesity), including those who underwent bariatric surgery.
interactions: Altered pharmacokinetics of antithrombotic drugs due to bariatric surgery-induced metabolic and gastrointestinal changes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oleic acid delivered to the distal small intestine could alleviate chronic constipation in patients who underwent bariatric surgery or were receiving GLP-1 analogues.
results_summary: Oleic acid delivered to the distal small intestine significantly increased bowel movements and softened stool consistency compared to the control group, with no significant differences in adverse effects or other gastrointestinal symptoms.
population_specificity: Fourteen adults with chronic constipation following bariatric surgery or GLP-1 analogue treatment.
effective_dosage: 21.25 g of oleic acid in microcapsules.
study_duration: Not specified (stable treatment for constipation for more than 4 weeks prior to intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of metabolic bariatric surgery versus glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonists in patients with type 2 diabetes and obesity, focusing on cardiovascular events, microvascular complications, and side effects.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with lower rates of major cardiovascular events and microvascular complications but had higher risks of alcohol/substance abuse, self-harm, and fractures compared to glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonists. The surgery group also showed better long-term glycemic control.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and complication rates of standard versus modified laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) techniques in patients with BMI>40 using the Clavien-Dindo classification system.
results_summary: The modified LSG technique showed significantly lower rates of minor and major complications, including acute bleeding and leakage, compared to the standard technique. Long-term complications like gallstone disease, GERD, thrombosis, malnutrition, and anemia were also reduced in the modified group, though renal lithiasis and depression showed no significant difference.
population_specificity: Patients with BMI>40 undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery as an effective intervention for severe obesity, particularly for patients who did not achieve desired results with pharmacotherapy and lifestyle interventions.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that bariatric surgery is an effective intervention for severe obesity but is associated with risks and is typically reserved for patients unresponsive to other treatments. It highlights the efficacy of incretin hormone agonists as an alternative or complementary approach.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity who have not achieved desired results with pharmacotherapy and lifestyle interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of one anastomosis gastric bypass (OAGB) relative to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and sleeve gastrectomy (SG) in the treatment of obesity.
results_summary: OAGB showed significantly higher percentage of excess weight loss at 1-year follow-up and lower body mass index at 5-year follow-up compared to RYGB and SG, but no significant differences in type-2 diabetes remission, complications, or gastroesophageal reflux disease rates. The overall quality of evidence was considered very low.
population_specificity: 854 patients from 11 randomized controlled trials, with 422 (49.4%) undergoing OAGB.
study_duration: Mean follow-up ranged from six months to five years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current state of bariatric surgery in Nigeria, its effectiveness as a treatment for obesity, and the need to improve its practice for obese Nigerians.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is the most cost-effective definitive treatment for all classes of obesity, leading to weight reduction, improvement or resolution of comorbidities, enhanced quality of life, and reduced all-cause mortality. In Nigeria, only 214 bariatric procedures were reported in 2023, with gastric balloon insertions being the most common.
population_specificity: Obese adults in Nigeria (estimated 15% of the adult population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to address the lack of specific guidelines for bariatric surgery in patients with obesity and metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).
results_summary: The study identified 11 clinical guidelines but noted gaps in interpretations for bariatric patients. It recommended initial screening with FIB-4 and transient hepatic elastography (VCTE) for patients with FIB-4 >1.3, though cutoff values for obese patients require further study. Liver biopsy was suggested for individualized cases, and family screening was advised for relatives of young patients with advanced fibrosis.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and MASLD undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of GLP1-RAs, particularly liraglutide, in enhancing weight loss outcomes after bariatric surgery compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that GLP1-RA therapy, especially liraglutide (1.8-3 mg), significantly reduced mean BMI and body weight percentage at six months post-surgery. Future studies should explore newer GLP1-RAs with weekly dosing and longer follow-up periods to assess durability.
population_specificity: 130 patients from three randomized controlled trials (RCTs) who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tailoring the biliopancreatic limb length based on total small bowel length (TSBL) in one anastomosis gastric bypass results in superior weight loss outcomes compared to a fixed 150 cm limb length.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in percentage total weight loss at one year between the standard (150 cm) and tailored biliopancreatic limb groups. Nutritional deficiencies and short-term complications were similar between groups, indicating that tailoring limb length is safe but not superior to the standard approach.
population_specificity: Patients meeting IFSO criteria for metabolic bariatric surgery, scheduled for primary one anastomosis gastric bypass.
effective_dosage: Standard (150 cm) or tailored (150 cm, 180 cm, or 210 cm based on TSBL) biliopancreatic limb lengths.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of bariatric surgery on the pharmacokinetics and clinical management of chronic pain medications, including non-opioids and opioids.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery alters the pharmacokinetics of medications like acetaminophen and opioids, complicating chronic pain management. It advocates for individualized medication approaches and safety monitoring rather than blanket recommendations or bans.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity who underwent bariatric surgery and require chronic pain management.
interactions: Mentions interactions with non-opioid and opioid medications, including acetaminophen, NSAIDs, antidepressants, and cannabinoids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the hospital costs of robotic versus laparoscopic bariatric surgery and assess whether robotic surgery offers clinical advantages.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in clinical outcomes or hospital stay between robotic and laparoscopic bariatric surgery, but robotic surgery was significantly more expensive. Subgroup analyses suggested lesser cost disparities in revisional surgery, where robotics might be more beneficial.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent robotic or laparoscopic bariatric surgery at the researchers' institution (122 initially, 42 after propensity score matching).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effects of bariatric surgery (BS) and conservative weight therapy (CWT) on weight loss and HIV metrics in patients living with HIV (PLWH).
results_summary: The BS group showed significant BMI reduction compared to CWT, with maintained efficacy of HIV treatments, suggesting BS is a safe and effective medium-term obesity treatment for PLWH.
population_specificity: 24 chronic HIV patients (10 underwent BS, 14 underwent CWT).
study_duration: Retrospective review from 2012-2018 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between weight loss and health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in individuals undergoing bariatric surgery in the UK using registry data.
results_summary: The study found that greater weight loss and remission of type 2 diabetes were independently associated with significant improvements in HRQoL following bariatric surgery. HRQoL improved rapidly post-surgery and plateaued, while BMI continued to decrease over 12 months.
population_specificity: UK patients undergoing primary bariatric surgery with baseline and at least one follow-up visit within a year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery as part of a comprehensive weight management strategy for obese patients.
results_summary: The study highlights bariatric surgery as an effective intervention for eligible patients, emphasizing its inclusion in a multi-pillar approach to obesity management alongside behavioral, nutritional, and pharmacological strategies.
population_specificity: Patients with a BMI of 30 kg/m² or greater, or overweight patients (BMI ≥27 kg/m²) with metabolic comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the overlooked scientific and clinical aspects of dumping syndrome, including its diagnostic criteria, pathogenesis, terminology, and management, particularly in the context of bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study highlights that dumping syndrome is a common complication post-bariatric surgery, affecting 25-50% of gastric surgery patients, with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass patients at particularly high risk (up to 40%). It calls for more research to establish guidelines for proper documentation and management of the condition.
population_specificity: Patients who have undergone bariatric surgery, particularly Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic effects of bariatric surgery on hyperuricemia and gout in obese patients, as well as explore adverse reactions and preventative strategies.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery effectively manages obesity and improves hyperuricemia and gout, but postoperative fluctuations in uric acid levels and acute gout attacks require attention. The review highlights both short-term and long-term outcomes and identifies gaps in preventative measures for complications.
population_specificity: Obese patients with hyperuricemia and/or gout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the timing of esketamine administration (before or after anesthesia) affects its efficacy in managing postoperative depression in patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that administering esketamine before anesthesia significantly reduced postoperative depression scores and increased plasma BDNF levels compared to post-anesthesia administration or placebo. No improvement was observed when esketamine was given after anesthesia.
population_specificity: 120 patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Single administration (2 hours before or after anesthesia induction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationships between disordered eating behaviors and typical dietary intake patterns among patients seeking metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS).
results_summary: The study found that objective overeating (OOE) was prevalent and linked to higher daily energy and macronutrient intake, with recurrent OOE associated with late-night eating. No significant associations were found between other disordered eating behaviors (e.g., objective binge eating) and contextual dietary factors.
population_specificity: Adults seeking metabolic and bariatric surgery at two academic medical centers in the United States (n = 140).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a social media-based, health professional-led educational and support program on long-term engagement, adherence to follow-up guidelines, self-care recommendations, and weight management after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that interactive health support on social media positively enhanced patient engagement, adherence to treatment recommendations, health outcomes, and overall well-being. Of the 214 participants, 101 completed the program, showing improvements in adherence and well-being.
population_specificity: Adults (≥18 years) who underwent bariatric surgery within the past 1 to 7 years, predominantly female (80.2%), mean age 43.8 years, mean BMI 30.2 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of bariatric surgery versus medical weight loss in achieving weight loss and subsequent eligibility for kidney transplantation in severely obese patients on dialysis.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery (MBS) was superior to medical weight loss (MM) in achieving weight loss prior to listing for kidney transplantation, though the sample size was small (9 treated patients). Larger studies are needed to confirm safety in patients with ESRD.
population_specificity: Patients on dialysis with a BMI of 40-55 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of magnetic sphincter augmentation (MSA) and subtotal gastrectomy with Roux-en-Y reconstruction (SGRY) in treating gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) following sleeve gastrectomy (SG).
results_summary: The study found that SGRY resulted in better symptom control and greater reduction in acid exposure compared to MSA, with 50% of SGRY patients achieving normalization of DeMeester scores versus 20% in the MSA group.
population_specificity: 92 patients (85 females, 7 males) with post-SG GERD, average BMI of 33.3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to uncover mechanisms, biomarkers, and predictive factors of weight loss, weight maintenance, and amelioration of obesity-related comorbidities following sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: The study collected extensive biosamples and clinical data from participants, with ongoing data analysis. Future research will explore variability in weight loss outcomes, particularly among Black and Hispanic patients, and identify factors predicting success.
population_specificity: 647 participants (79% female, average age 38, 68% Hispanic, 20% non-Hispanic Black, 11% non-Hispanic White) from two bariatric surgery clinics in New York City.
study_duration: Data collection spans up to 10 years post-surgery, with current follow-up until December 2031.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and key anesthetic considerations of metabolic and bariatric surgery for adolescents with severe obesity.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is safe and effective for adolescents with severe obesity, with comprehensive preoperative evaluations and advanced perioperative management reducing complications. Enhanced recovery protocols improved outcomes and shortened hospital stays.
population_specificity: Adolescents with severe obesity (class 2 or higher).
interactions: Effects of antiobesity medications on gastric emptying and hemodynamic stability were noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal number of suction drains in abdominoplasty procedures to minimize complications and improve patient outcomes.
results_summary: Insertion of a single drain was associated with lower rates of surgical site infections, hypertrophic scars, and wound dehiscence but a higher risk of seroma and need for revision surgery compared to no drains.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing abdominoplasty procedures performed by a single surgeon.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare weight loss sustainability between perioperative intragastric balloon (IGB) placement and GLP1RA (semaglutide) initiation in Veterans with obesity.
results_summary: IGB led to faster initial weight loss (-12.7 kg vs. -9.4 kg at 6 months), but weight regain occurred post-removal (average 3 kg at 1 year). Semaglutide users continued losing weight during the same period.
population_specificity: US Veterans (mean age 54, 69% male, mean BMI 37) enrolled in a multidisciplinary weight management program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of GLP-1 receptor agonists (GLP-1 RA) in patients experiencing weight regain or insufficient weight loss after metabolic bariatric surgery (MBS).
results_summary: The study found that GLP-1 RA treatment resulted in a mean weight loss of -7.02 kg and a BMI reduction of 3.07 kg/m², concluding it as a safe and effective intervention for post-MBS weight management.
population_specificity: Patients with weight regain or insufficient weight loss after metabolic bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Liraglutide 3 mg per day, semaglutide 1 mg once weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in psoriasis symptoms, severity, and treatment requirements in obese patients undergoing Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery (MBS).
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in BMI postoperatively and a reduction in psoriasis severity, with fewer patients requiring systemic treatments after MBS.
population_specificity: 32 adult patients with obesity and psoriasis, predominantly female (n = 29), mean age 46.6 ± 10.8 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the efficacy and versatility of Endobariatric and Metabolic Therapies (EBMTs) in obesity management, comparing their use to strategic chess systems for tailored, patient-centric approaches.
results_summary: The study found that EBMTs offer reversible, adjustable, and minimally invasive options for weight loss and metabolic improvement, but their adoption is hindered by lack of awareness, perceived costs, and limited training. Gastric-focused EBMTs reduce stomach capacity, while intestinal-focused EBMTs target hormonal regulation and nutrient absorption.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity management context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of gestational weight gain in pregnancy after metabolic bariatric surgery, focusing on sleeve gastrectomy and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
results_summary: The study highlights that metabolic bariatric surgery is effective for severe obesity but can lead to adverse pregnancy outcomes like fetal growth restriction, emphasizing the importance of managing gestational weight gain.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age undergoing metabolic bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the methods and mechanisms, including bariatric surgery, for treating nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The abstract indicates that bariatric surgery is one of the methods reviewed for treating NAFLD, but specific results or outcomes related to its efficacy are not detailed. The review suggests combining different treatments may be effective for NAFLD.
population_specificity: Not specified (general NAFLD population implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical response to gastric electrical stimulation (GES) in patients with refractory postsurgical gastroparesis, particularly focusing on those with a history of bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that GES significantly improved upper gastrointestinal symptoms in patients with refractory postsurgical gastroparesis, including those who had undergone bariatric surgery. However, GES did not enhance gastric emptying test results, and anorexia remained a notable symptom post-GES in the bariatric surgery group.
population_specificity: 185 patients with drug-refractory postsurgical gastroparesis, categorized by surgical history (bariatric surgery, Nissen fundoplication, and others).
study_duration: Evaluations were conducted at baseline, after temporary GES placement, and 6 months after permanent GES placement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how genetic variants influence metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) outcomes in morbidly obese patients.
results_summary: The systematic review identified associations between various genetic polymorphisms and post-surgery weight loss, metabolic, cardiovascular, taste, and eating behavior effects, suggesting genetic factors play a role in MBS outcomes. However, further research with larger sample sizes and extended follow-up is needed to clarify these effects.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients undergoing metabolic and bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the safety and efficacy of bariatric surgery in patients with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder compared to controls without psychiatric comorbidity.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is safe and effective in carefully selected patients with schizophrenia, with no evidence of worsening the psychiatric disease course. Weight loss and metabolic outcomes were comparable between patients with schizophrenia and controls.
population_specificity: Patients with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder who underwent bariatric surgery, compared to controls without psychiatric comorbidity.
study_duration: Follow-up at 12, 24, 36, 48, and 60 months after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a very low-calorie diet (VLCD) versus Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) on weight reduction, body composition changes, and comorbidity resolution over 12 weeks.
results_summary: The study found that both VLCD and RYGB were effective interventions for weight reduction and improving body composition, with RYGB being highlighted as the most effective treatment for severe obesity.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity (BMI ≥ 37.5 kg/m²) at an obesity clinic in Thailand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and safety of robotic-assisted bariatric surgery, specifically focusing on the Hugo platform for procedures like Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (RYGB).
results_summary: The abstract suggests robotic-assisted surgery may enhance technical and clinical outcomes in bariatric procedures, particularly for complex operations like RYGB, but does not provide specific results.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of probiotic supplementation combined with a weight loss program and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) on weight loss, eating behavior, food addiction, and related hormone levels in patients with food addiction and weight regain after metabolic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The probiotic group showed significant reductions in weight, BMI, and fat mass, along with improved eating behavior and food addiction compared to the placebo group. Additionally, leptin levels decreased and oxytocin levels increased significantly in the probiotic group.
population_specificity: Patients with food addiction and weight regain after metabolic bariatric surgery (n=50).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of resmetirom on MASH treatment and propose a multidisciplinary approach including metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) to improve patient outcomes.
results_summary: The study highlights that resmetirom shows promise in treating MASH, but its long-term benefits and ethnic differences require further research. Integrating resmetirom with MBS and lifestyle interventions may improve liver-related and cardiometabolic outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with non-cirrhotic MASH and moderate to advanced liver fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and comparative effectiveness of bariatric surgery for severe adolescent obesity.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery (Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and vertical sleeve gastrectomy) reduced mean BMI by approximately 30% at 1 year, with minor and major perioperative complications experienced by 15% and 8% of patients, respectively. Surgery was found to be the most effective intervention for severe adolescent obesity.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 12 to younger than 18 years with severe obesity (BMI ≥120% of the 95th percentile).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an evidence-based intraoperative care pathway for minimally invasive Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) to improve healthcare delivery and quality.
results_summary: The study provided evidence-based recommendations for intraoperative care of RYGB patients, covering preoperative holding, intraoperative management, and concurrent procedures, based on a review of literature from 2001 to 2019.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing minimally invasive Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).
study_duration: Not applicable (care pathway development, not an intervention study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the perioperative analgesic efficacy of subcostal anterior QLB versus TAPB in reducing opioid consumption and postoperative pain in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that subcostal anterior QLB may offer advantages over TAPB, including a wider block plane and longer maintenance time, potentially reducing opioid use and postoperative nausea and vomiting. However, definitive results were pending as the study was still in progress.
population_specificity: 66 obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in reducing gallstone risk and managing complications related to cholelithiasis.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery, along with significant weight reduction, can reduce the high risk of gallbladder stone formation, with ursodeoxycholic acid as a preventive measure. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is recommended for symptomatic gallstones due to increasing risks of recurrence or complications.
population_specificity: General adult population, particularly those undergoing significant weight reduction via diet or bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery in resolving metabolic-associated steatohepatitis (MASH), improving liver fibrosis, and reducing cardiovascular risks in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that substantial weight loss after bariatric surgery leads to significant and sustained resolution of MASH, improvement in liver fibrosis, and a decreased risk of major cardiovascular adverse events.
population_specificity: Obese patients with metabolic-associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD) or metabolic-associated steatohepatitis (MASH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of bariatric surgery for weight loss in patients with heart failure (HFrEF or HFpEF) and its impact on HF hospitalizations and mortality.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery showed moderate efficacy and safety in patients with preoperative HF or left ventricular dysfunction, with reductions in HF hospitalizations and medium-term mortality. The study also noted encouraging safety and weight loss efficacy of GLP-1 agonists in HFpEF, though concerns remain for advanced HFrEF.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (HFrEF or HFpEF) and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of different revisional bariatric procedures after inadequate results from sleeve gastrectomy (SG).
results_summary: SADI showed superior weight loss (%TWL and %EWL) and lower complication rates compared to OAGB, RYGB, and re-SG. Re-SG had the highest complication rates, while SADI also demonstrated favorable effects on reflux.
population_specificity: Patients with inadequate outcomes after sleeve gastrectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and review the top 10 seminal articles on laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) to highlight its safety, outcomes, and physiological effects.
results_summary: The study found that the top 10 most cited papers on LSG emphasize its operative safety, positive patient outcomes, surgical techniques, and physiological changes, supporting its widespread acceptance.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on literature review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Laparoscopic Sleeve Gastrectomy (LSG) and Laparoscopic Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (LRYGB) in terms of weight loss, comorbidity remission, and quality of life.
results_summary: LRYGB resulted in greater weight loss and higher remission rates for type 2 diabetes and dyslipidemia compared to LSG at 5 years, but LSG had a lower morbidity rate. No significant differences were found in hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea remission, quality of life, or mortality between the two procedures.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing bariatric surgery for obesity treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline the multidisciplinary treatment approach for obesity, including the role of bariatric surgery when appropriate.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that bariatric surgery is part of a comprehensive treatment strategy for obesity, alongside nutrition, physical activity, behavioral therapy, and pharmacotherapy. It does not provide specific outcomes or efficacy data for bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity, as classified by body mass index, in the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the characteristics and outcomes of esophagogastric cancer (EGC) in patients who had undergone bariatric surgery compared to non-bariatric patients.
results_summary: Bariatric patients were diagnosed with EGC at a younger age and had worse nodal involvement, but surgical outcomes were comparable to non-bariatric patients. The study suggests clinical and endoscopic surveillance is important as EGC can occur earlier in bariatric patients.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent EGC surgery, including a bariatric surgery group (N=10) and a non-bariatric group (N=259).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze trends in isolated splenic abscesses, including causes such as post-bariatric surgery complications.
results_summary: The study found that iatrogenic causes, including post-bariatric surgery, are increasingly reported for isolated splenic abscesses, but non-surgical treatments can sometimes be definitive.
population_specificity: Patients with isolated splenic abscesses from 1900-2022, including those post-bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the surgical outcomes of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) and robotic sleeve gastrectomy (RSG) to determine their relative safety, efficacy, and cost-effectiveness.
results_summary: Both RSG and LSG showed comparable rates of readmission, conversion, mortality, and complications, with similar weight loss efficacy. However, RSG was associated with longer operative times, prolonged hospitalization, and higher costs compared to LSG.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (LSG or RSG) for obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of bariatric surgery on diabetes-related foot complications (DFC) in patients with type 2 diabetes and determine whether DFC symptoms improve post-surgery.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery showed a 51% lower risk of DFC in observational studies but no significant reduction in randomized controlled trials. It improved diabetic neuropathy assessment parameters and symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes at risk of or with existing diabetes-related foot complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the psychological state and quality of life of obese patients before and one year after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that 34.1% of patients had personality disorders, 31.8% showed anomalous food behavior, and 43.2% had low mood pre-surgery. Quality of life improved one year post-surgery, particularly for those who underwent sleeve gastrectomy.
population_specificity: 71 obese patients awaiting bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the perioperative experiences and outcomes of patients with a BMI ≥ 70 undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found significant BMI reductions (7.84% at 30 days, 20.13% at 6 months, and 26.83% at 1 year) with low 30-day complications (0.7%), though ED visits increased over time (14.4% at 30 days, 25% at 1 year). Readmission and reoperation rates at 1 year were 6.45% and 4.83%, respectively.
population_specificity: Patients with BMI ≥ 70 (mean age 41.7 years, 86.9% female, 66.7% black).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare intra- and postoperative outcomes between robotic and laparoscopic approaches for sleeve gastrectomy, duodenal switch, and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in 30-day morbidity and mortality between robotic and laparoscopic approaches, except for a slightly higher risk of unplanned reoperation in robotic RYGB and wound disruption in robotic SG. Operative times were longer for robotic procedures but decreased over the study period.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent SG, DS, and RYGB between 2015 and 2021 (n=1,178,886).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery as a beneficial adjunct treatment for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in conjunction with other therapies.
results_summary: The study found that weight loss, including through bariatric surgery, is a beneficial adjunct to OSA treatment, improving symptoms alongside other interventions like positive airway pressure. However, no mortality benefit was demonstrated for any OSA therapy, including bariatric surgery, in randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), particularly those with comorbidities like obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term impact of metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) on Quality of Life (QoL) in Indian patients with obesity over a 10-year period.
results_summary: The study found that MBS led to substantial and long-term improvements in overall QoL for up to 10 years in obese individuals. The data supports MBS as an effective intervention for enhancing QoL in this population.
population_specificity: Indian patients with obesity (mean age 43.28 ± 11.96 years, 37.43% men, 62.57% females, mean preoperative BMI 45.71 ± 10.38 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in obesity management, particularly for menopausal women, and highlight the importance of a multidisciplinary approach involving gynecologists.
results_summary: The abstract suggests bariatric surgery is reserved for severe obesity or obesity-related complications, emphasizing tailored strategies for menopausal women due to hormonal changes affecting weight management. It underscores the pivotal role of gynecologists in coordinating care and monitoring treatment effects.
population_specificity: Menopausal women with obesity or overweight and risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of FGF19 in metabolism, particularly its potential as a therapeutic target for obesity and type 2 diabetes, and its rapid increase following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that FGF19 has antidiabetic and antiobesogenic effects, with an inverse correlation between FGF19 levels and body mass or visceral adiposity. Bariatric surgery was associated with a rapid increase in FGF19, highlighting its metabolic benefits.
population_specificity: Animal models and cell lines (human clinical trials mentioned for FGF19 analog aldafermin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically assess the safety, weight loss outcomes, improvement in comorbidities, and complications of the SASI bypass compared to other bariatric surgeries (SG and OAGB).
results_summary: SASI bypass showed improved weight loss and better remission/improvement in T2DM, DL, and OSA compared to SG, with no significant differences in outcomes or complication rates when compared to OAGB. The complication rate of SASI was similar to both SG and OAGB.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of weight loss from dietary intervention and bariatric surgery (RYGB, SG, LAGB) on gonadal, corticotropic, somatotropic, and thyroid axes over 3 years.
results_summary: Weight loss led to increased total testosterone in males and decreased total testosterone in females, with bariatric procedures showing more pronounced androgen reduction in females. The study also noted changes in adrenocorticotropic hormone and insulin-like growth factor-1 but no significant thyrotrophin changes.
population_specificity: 61 adults with BMI >30 kg/m² seeking weight loss interventions.

study_goal: The abstract does not specify a research goal regarding bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract does not report any findings related to bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Adolescents with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss challenges clinicians face in evaluating, assessing, and prescribing micronutrient supplementation for patients with malabsorptive conditions.
results_summary: The abstract highlights limitations in assessing micronutrient deficiencies, challenges during parenteral product shortages, and difficulties in transitioning patients to enteral/oral nutrition, but does not present specific results on Bariatric Surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with malabsorptive conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review new pharmacological treatments and modern metabolic surgery for obesity, focusing on personalized treatment approaches and long-term care considerations.
results_summary: The study highlights improved weight loss with new treatment options, emphasizing the need for tailored, long-term care to enhance overall health and wellbeing, while addressing clinical challenges like eating disorders and mental health issues.
population_specificity: Adults and children with obesity, including specific subgroups like older adults and those with neuropsychiatric disorders or intellectual disabilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of preoperative probiotic therapy on bariatric surgery outcomes.
results_summary: The study conducted a 12-week randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial but did not report specific outcomes regarding the efficacy of probiotics in improving bariatric surgery results.
population_specificity: 48 patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if preoperative 1 mg-DST serum cortisol levels could predict the effectiveness of bariatric surgery in severely obese patients without Cushing syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that lower preoperative 1 mg-DST levels and lower insulin resistance were associated with greater weight loss after bariatric surgery, with a significant negative correlation between 1 mg-DST levels and percent total weight loss (%TWL).
population_specificity: 98 severely obese patients without Cushing syndrome who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the pharmacokinetics and safety of full-dose rivaroxaban in patients who underwent bariatric surgery (RYGB or SG) compared to obese and healthy controls.
results_summary: Post-bariatric surgery patients showed altered rivaroxaban pharmacokinetics with reduced absorption, but the variations were deemed unlikely to be clinically significant. Bioequivalence criteria were not met for BS groups compared to controls, though the class III obesity group met them at steady state.
population_specificity: Adult patients with stable weight after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) or sleeve gastrectomy (SG), compared to subjects with class III obesity and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of liraglutide for weight management in patients experiencing weight regain after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that liraglutide is well tolerated and promotes significant weight loss in patients with weight regain post-bariatric surgery, supporting its use as a therapeutic option.
population_specificity: Mostly female (50%), aged 36 to 55 years, with a mean BMI of 39.4 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop Italian guidelines for endoscopic bariatric treatment of obesity by assessing its efficacy and safety compared to other interventions.
results_summary: The study outlines a systematic approach to evaluate endoscopic bariatric procedures, including systematic reviews and meta-analyses, focusing on efficacy and safety over at least 52 weeks. The guidelines address indications, revisional surgery, temporary procedures, and complications.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥14 years with BMI ≥27 kg/m².
study_duration: Minimum follow-up of 52 weeks (6 months for temporary procedures).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of cfRNA biomarkers in predicting metabolic outcomes related to obesity and identifying patients likely to benefit from bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that cfRNA analysis shows promise as a prognostic tool for obesity-related comorbidities and may help predict favorable clinical outcomes post-bariatric surgery. It also highlighted the potential of cfRNA in monitoring disease progression and treatment efficacy in diabetes.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity-related comorbidities (e.g., diabetes, dyslipidemia, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the additive effects of depression and obesity on neural correlates of inhibitory control and explore inflammation as a potential connecting pathway.
results_summary: Concurrent depression and obesity were linked to increased functional connectivity in specific brain regions, and exploratory analysis suggested associations between inflammation markers and altered connectivity. The study supports an additive detrimental effect of depression and obesity on neurocognitive functioning, possibly mediated by inflammation.
population_specificity: 64 individuals with obesity and varying degrees of depressed mood.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of anti-obesity medications as an adjunct therapy to bariatric surgery for preventing weight regain or enhancing weight loss.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is the most potent therapy for obesity, inducing significant weight loss, but some patients experience weight regain over time. Anti-obesity medications can serve as an effective adjunct therapy to boost post-bariatric weight loss or prevent regain.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery and may experience weight regain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine and compare sexual self-concept in women with obesity before and after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that sexual self-concept scores were significantly higher post-surgery (240.26) compared to pre-surgery (200.26), with the highest scores in the area of sexual depression. Higher education and certain living conditions (e.g., no other individuals in the house, non-smoking spouse) were associated with increased odds of surgery and higher self-concept scores.
population_specificity: Women with obesity referred to obesity clinics in Tehran, Iran (2020-2021).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which vertical sleeve gastrectomy (VSG) contributes to weight loss and remission of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found that VSG effectively promotes weight loss and improves or cures T2DM by enhancing incretin secretion (especially GLP-1), modifying gut microbiota, and through weight loss-dependent mechanisms. The alterations in the gastrointestinal tract post-VSG may improve insulin secretion and resistance.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of metabolic and bariatric surgery on transplant outcomes for patients with obesity awaiting solid organ transplantation.
results_summary: The review presents current literature and expert opinions on metabolic and bariatric surgery as a therapeutic option for obese patients awaiting organ transplants, highlighting recent recommendations, pharmacologic considerations, and psychological factors. However, the absence of level one evidence indicates gaps in high-quality research for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity awaiting solid organ transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of metabolic and bariatric surgery on transplant outcomes for patients with obesity awaiting solid organ transplantation.
results_summary: The review presents current literature and expert opinions on metabolic and bariatric surgery as a therapeutic option for obese patients awaiting organ transplants, highlighting recent recommendations, pharmacologic considerations, and psychological factors. However, the absence of level one evidence indicates gaps in high-quality research for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity awaiting solid organ transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of photobiomodulation (PBM) for treating chronic knee pain in obese patients undergoing pre-surgical rehabilitation for bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study protocol but does not provide results, as it is a trial protocol and not a completed study.
population_specificity: Obese patients with chronic knee pain who are candidates for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers reviewed recent advancements and pressing topics in liver transplantation, including surgical techniques, indications, and outcomes.
results_summary: The abstract highlights improvements in liver transplantation outcomes due to advanced techniques, refined indications, and better donor selection, but does not address bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage liver disease, acute/chronic/metabolic liver conditions, or liver cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of the gut-liver axis in MAFLD development and the potential of GLP-1 RAs as pleiotropic agents for its treatment.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that GLP-1 RAs improve glycemia regulation, reduce lipid synthesis, enhance fatty acid oxidation, and induce hepatic autophagy, contributing to MAFLD amelioration. Gut microbiota modulation by these drugs may also play a role in treatment effectiveness.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of MAFLD and GLP-1 RAs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess residual arterial supply to the stomach after bariatric surgery using arterial-phase CT to aid in diagnosing complications and planning future procedures.
results_summary: The study found consistent identification of arterial supply through the left gastric artery (LGA) in all RYGB and SG cases, with good to excellent patency rates for LGA, RGA, and GEA. Gastric perforators were frequently observed, particularly via LGA, suggesting preserved blood supply post-surgery.
population_specificity: 46 patients who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) or sleeve gastrectomy (SG) at 3 academic institutions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of revisional surgeries after one-anastomosis gastric bypass (OAGB) versus Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).
results_summary: OAGB patients required revisions primarily due to postoperative complications (e.g., GERD), while RYGB patients needed revisions mainly for insufficient weight loss. Postoperative complications and hospital stay length were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥18 years who underwent prior OAGB or RYGB surgery across 12 Polish centers (2010–2020).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of bariatric surgery between inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and non-IBD patients, focusing on weight loss, complications, and postoperative effects.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was equally effective for weight loss in IBD and non-IBD patients at 1-year follow-up, but IBD patients had higher risks of acute renal failure, hemorrhage, and readmission. Postoperative complications were more frequent in IBD patients undergoing RYGB compared to SG, and steroid use declined significantly in IBD patients post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with and without inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the incidence of adverse events related to antiobesity medications (GLP-1RAs vs. non-GLP-1RAs) after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found no increased risk of adverse events with GLP-1RA use compared to non-GLP-1RA medications post-bariatric surgery. Initiating AOMs ≥12 months after surgery was associated with lower AE risk than earlier initiation.
population_specificity: Patients aged 16-65 years who underwent laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy and initiated AOMs (83% female, median age 47.8 years).
study_duration: Median duration from surgery to AOM exposure was 30 months.
